header.rec_loc: In the ticket office at the TME working party near Taunton.
header.topics: Successful career inventing and marketing printing systems. Working in Germany at exhibitions.
header.activity: Talking while taking a break from the TME working party near Taunton.

speaker.dialect_rep: I may have a slight Somerset accent
speaker.occupation: retired artist and antique dealer/gallery owner

body.u: be careful you don't fall off the back there won't you're right on the edge
and I just thought I'd er
well wwell for the tape we're sitting in a very small sig erm ticket office here at the model engineers and is with me this morning and he's going to talk about well why are you a model engineer?
I think it's an engineering background my father was
and erm I studied u er engineering at at college actually and then erm went into engineering initially as a po as a post as a erm graduate apprentice for
erm ending up at their applied research laboratories at
and er working on just er to start with guided weapons and then on er satellite communications
then I erm formed a company with a couple of friends and erm we sold printing equipment all over the world
yeah we actually modify we actually produce modifications for existing equipment
erm we'd all worked for one company who was at the time was a majorly a brand leader in the area and we produced electronics for the print industry
right right because erm in the in the I I worked for newspapers for quite a long time for about sixteen years I worked for the and did you do anything at all with with the the press?
I I never really used to sp most most of my time was spent in the laboratory I
I I ran the R and B department
erm right so you were research and development and erm really you're the boffin behind the the engineering not not the sales person or the
no occasionally we we'd ggo out to see customers when there was
a particular k a particular problem the company was small enough so that you erm er everybody had a go at everything practically

er the maximum it was about thirty
but most of the time it was about twelve fifteen something like that
right right and erm you must have seen a lot of changes with printing techniques over the years
erm yes erm the er I worked for ttwo companies erm before b going independent one was
and so I saw the development of the scanner from the early analogue scanners to the later digital scanners and so on
and then it moved to a liner type and produced one of their desi er or designed one of their miniature scanners which er was the er sort of last generation before the desktop really took over and er

yes I remember the erm in there was a sort of like a it was like a piece of cardboard er was it called Dycron? Di er er er a system where it was impressed on a piece of card and then that was impressed onto a roll that was put on a roll and then it was rolled out what
was that method called? that came somewhere in the middle
yyes I've I I well I never worked on the press side so I I
oh you didn't well they adopted
that method at one stage and what the the card the residue cardboard that they left behind I used to paint on I used to sort of try and
bend it back the other way and paint on the back
I wish I hadn't got rid of some of those though they were er they might be worth something today erm but er a lot of erm these processes they're good for a while and then they just go don't they?
they do yes I mean the the although some of the high quality work is still done on the kind of scanners
most of it's now gone to the flatbeds which you put on your desktop
yes yeah in the metallic printing erm they've still got in university and a lot of the universities now and in the art departments they use old printing blocks
a lot of the time and they put

you see it inintegrated in art and erm I have erm two blocks that I use for my initials when I do a painting I frequently you ink them up and stick them on at the bottom if they're in a piece of abstract work I mean it's not relevant in something that's smaller but er yeah so erm and and now you've retired and erm have ha er what have you got on the go as far as engines concerns er any engines at all?
er yes I tend to build things in parallel because I like
to be able to swap between different scales and
and so I'm building a two and a half inch gauge model of one of the American er wartime austerity locomotives
a five inch gauge Manning Wardle
and a seven and a quarter inch gauge Hunslet
no no just just enough to keep me happy
so how much time do you spend in the workshop every day do you think?
erm it obviously varies but er erm I quite often spend the whole day in the workshop
yeah yeah and do you find that if you don't get your model engineering done it ma it impacts on your erm er humour?
not particularly no but I I do s yes I I you do suffer from withdrawal symptoms
if you don't er get your fix occasionally

it yes erm I notice erm obviously cos I live with I I I notice that he he gets he does he he never gets cross but he he does get slightly irritated I think if he can't get and do what he wants to do he feel he he's in a middle of a project and he wants to and was saying the same you know he he he just gets very disgruntled if he can't get on with it
I think probably we a we all tend to feel that way yes
and I'm the same with my art if I've got to if I'm diverted by doing housework or things that I really don't want to do I I do get grumpy
and I need to get erm I do I actually get very temperamental altogether so I've just got to get in there and do it you you see so you've been coming on these working parties now for how long?
virtually since I joined the clubs
one one time there were only three of us who normally turned up
and so erm I also edit the magazine so I'm dubbed as the three musketeers
er er how did it work out? and
yes I like it erm cos did for a while didn't he?
so I was I was going to I know that I'm too late for this edition er but I want to put a little thank you in to everybody who's erm who's you know given their fifteen minutes to
and also at the same time put something in to ask if there are any other members who would like to talk at some time when I come back
so erm so how are you finding the challenge of doing ?

hand it over to somebody else

erm it takes up most of a week basically
that's a big contribution as a volunteer isn't it really?
but it's your hobby as well

erm I've never had a contributor who give me any any contribution but I'd welcome it yes anything new I mean it's

I was actually thinking about this erm show you're planning next year and erm thinking of having s I mean I I'm a member of the model engineers because always pays for me to be a member I wonder how many other of the ladies are me actual members and if they are erm whether we ought to have some sort of contribution in there because we are actually members and I sometimes think
nothnothing big just just you know just some lines every now and then would be nice

erm occasionally from the tickers and erm
so yes it was no real reason why there shouldn't be a section
eeven put something in from the nomads occasionally

yeah so erm erm when you were doing your job originally looking back at the beginning of your career after you left university erm did you did you sort of fall into that erm way of working or did or was it something that you really wanted to do?
oh no I I knew I wanted to go into design and development
into R and D right from the start
and erm say I although I've erm I er well whe we started the company I was a director of the company so I had reresponsibilities
but erm I was always involved the technical side yes
right what would you say over the years was the most satisfying project you worked on?
or one of them you know
erm well in some respects the the well when we were working when we were er became independent erm we erm produced an interface between the established erm graphic art scanners
and we were virtually the first people in the world to do this so we
yeah one year we exported ninety-two percent of our product
and we got a Queen's Award for Industry for it
erm so it was that was perhaps the most in some respects the most interesting
where were where did you export it?
erm we a lot went er to the States
erm one of the directors was married to a Japanese lady
and we exported quite a lot to Japan
erm and in and the rest of Europe in general
we had quite an active agent in Germany
and erm so virtually the whole of the world
the but it because you were more er you were obviously research and development did you you did get sometimes obviously a chance to go to these places did you? or or travel at all?
er yes in erm er my wife had a a horse and we had a horse box
so the my company car was a erm a Discovery
and that was used to tow the company's trailer whenever we went to a show
and so I often ended up driving the thing down the autobahns to Dusseldorf or somewhere
all sorts of bits and pieces for the show

yeah yeah they're very fast those autobahns aren't they? well erm we lived in Germany for a while and erm I think it was before we really had very many motorways er it was nineteen f I'm talking nineteen fifty-eight

and erm in those days I remember travelling on the autobahn and thinking well was it in nineteen fifty or? I went back to Germany in erm nineteen sixty-seven as well so it could have been nineteen sixty-seven but they s their roads seemed to be far more far faster and bigger than than what we had in England but it may be just me mm
yes I no I just took them took them my stride yes
you just er yyeah you do really just er
with three tonnes behind and a Land Rover
you're not gonna go very quickly anyway
no no and so when you were there and ththese exhibitions you were talking to people as well were you?
in fact the idea for the interface really we we first put out at a a show just to sort of see what the kind of response would be
and erm we got people from all sorts of parts of th of the er show
this would be interesting so that was really what er pushed us into doing it

absolutely I mean I've been to with to er where they do the huge erm industrial show for the railways and also I went to with him in fact trying to find him the place the site was so big that trying to find on the site was really difficult erm
and it took so long to get there and I used to find I'd get there and find he was deep in conversation with a potential customer and which I of course wouldn't wouldn't even wink at him you know
erm and then I'd have to find all my way back

so erm it was a bit of a shame really and erm you know there you go but erm and that's over now and that twenty years of that erm yes it's it's over he was there a lot longer so erm did you meet your wife at work? or
erm I got a er call from one of the other secretaries saying that erm I knew her vaguely but not very well
and er saying that she'd broken down
and erm since I was er interested in cars then I got er it w it was suggested we were working late and erm I think we were about the only people around
and er so suggested we went out and rescued her so
and er we m er sort of struck up a friendship after that
oh right oh that's a very nice story
yeah that's a very nice story erm so erm do you have any other hobbies mm er besides engineering? I mea you probably don't have time but do you have anything at all that you're interested in apart?
erm I although I haven't sailed much recently I
sail erm I erm restore historic cars as well

but I have done occasionally in the past yes

he owns a TVR and we took one on a rally in Spain
a couple of years ago which was

and erm you know there there you are

we we're going to for Christmas so er
